channel.title: Comments on: Sketch of a Literary Scene
channel.description: Critical Collaboration on the Middle East, South Asia, and Africa

item.title: By: Mahmoud Heidarian Vancouver
item.dc:creator: Mahmoud Heidarian Vancouver
item.description: It's a shame you don't have a donate button! I'd definitely donate to this brilliant blog! I suppose for now i'll settle for book-marking and adding your RSS feed to my Google account. I look forward to new updates and will talk about this site with my Facebook group. Talk soon!
item.content:encoded: It’s a shame you don’t have a donate button! I’d definitely donate to this brilliant blog! I suppose for now i’ll settle for book-marking and adding your RSS feed to my Google account. I look forward to new updates and will talk about this site with my Facebook group. Talk soon!

item.title: By: Mahmoud Heidarian Vancouver BC
item.dc:creator: Mahmoud Heidarian Vancouver BC
item.description: I’m impressed, I have to say. Really hardly ever do I encounter a blog that’s both educative and entertaining, and let me tell you, you could have hit the nail on the head. Your concept is excellent; the issue is something that not enough people are talking intelligently about. I'm very happy that I stumbled across this in my seek for one thing referring to this.
item.content:encoded: I’m impressed, I have to say. Really hardly ever do I encounter a blog that’s both educative and entertaining, and let me tell you, you could have hit the nail on the head. Your concept is excellent; the issue is something that not enough people are talking intelligently about. I’m very happy that I stumbled across this in my seek for one thing referring to this.

item.title: By: Mustafa Mudathir A
item.dc:creator: Mustafa Mudathir A
item.description: Hi Max Nice piece on Khartoum! This city has deteriorated beyond what one would expect from corrupt city managment. Until the first devaluation of the Sudanese pound in 1978, Khartoum was a well-kept, clean and busy city. Your description brought back lots of memories of the cultural scene of the seventies when we as dwellers of Omdurman, the Mahadi's stronghold-turned-into- a city, were able to cross the bridge on the Nile. We would first go for an ice cream or juice in the open-air cafe with it is famous central square-The Athenée, wrongly conveyed to you as Etienne. Then we would proceed along alJamhouriya street where bookshops and a place for selling used stamps would delay our progression to Khartoum University. Your mention of Bringi and Kamal Eljizouli nailed down all the nostalgia!
item.content:encoded:
Hi Max
Nice piece on Khartoum!
This city has deteriorated beyond what one would expect from corrupt city
managment. Until the first devaluation of the Sudanese pound in 1978, Khartoum was a well-kept, clean and busy city. Your description brought back lots of memories of the cultural scene of the seventies when we as dwellers of Omdurman, the Mahadi’s stronghold-turned-into- a city, were able to cross the bridge on the Nile. We would first go for an ice cream or juice in the open-air cafe with it is famous central square-The Athenée, wrongly conveyed to you as Etienne. Then we would proceed along alJamhouriya street where bookshops and a place for selling used stamps would delay our progression to Khartoum University.
Your mention of Bringi and Kamal Eljizouli nailed down all the nostalgia!

item.title: By: Looking for Literature in Khartoum | Arabic Literature (in English)
item.dc:creator: Looking for Literature in Khartoum | Arabic Literature (in English)
item.description: [...] Max Shmookler — who previously wrote about “How To Separate Mediocre, Good, and Great Stories for Translation” and his work in assembling a collection of Sudanese short stories — now explores the literary scene in Khartoum in a post that originally appeared on Baraza: [...]
